title: Angular momentum cons - disks 1 and 2 collide

content.question: Disk <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 1 equals 6.0 kilogram meters squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>·</mo><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and rotates clockwise about the perpendicular axis passing through its center at an angular speed of <math alttext="5.0 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></math>, as shown in the figure. Directly above Disk <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is Disk <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, which has rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 2 equals 3.0 kilogram meters squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>·</mo><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and which also rotates about the axis passing through its center, but at an unknown angular speed. Disk <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is dropped down onto Disk <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and at a later time the two disks are rotating together in the clockwise direction at the same final angular speed of <math alttext="1.0 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></math>. What was the initial angular speed of Disk <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> ?
